The 3/5ths compromise was actually a device to penalize slave states for not freeing their people. The Slave states wanted their slaves to be counted as a full person so they would receive more representatives in the congress, but the Free states thought it was a travesty that people that weren't even free to elect their representatives were being represented by people that would perpetually keep them in slavery.

A lot of people look at the 3/5ths compromise and say "Ooh that's evil and bad." however, the compromise was specifically invented as a way to help foster freedom for slaves who would then count as a full person for purposes of representation.

In practice though the checks and balances system works the opposite. Congress is weakest as every other branch can perform a form of veto on them and newer checks such as lobby groups and think tanks can completely prevent them from functioning, while they also check themselves too well and end up passing laws very rarely or very watered down.

Meanwhile, the court is actually the most powerful, they have the fewest actual checks and balances on them and can legislate laws regulated at the time only by themselves and that they can only do it if there is ambiguity or problems with the laws. They have passed numerous of the most important federal laws in American history including overturning racial laws or limiting corporate political spending. They only real way to stop their decisions is for congress to pass a law overruling the decision, and we all know how weak congress is.

I see a lot of people talking about how the Presidency doesn't seem to have much power in the US government, and that is technically true if you're looking at constitutional power, but practically it is the most powerful. This is because the president has democratic legitimacy, like Congress, but since he is a solitary figure he can act more quickly and clearly than congress. Since Teddy Roosevelt, presidents have used this persuasive advantage to bypass congress and appeal directly to the people. Especially if he/she has recently been elected, the executive can use this strategy to convert good will and political capital into a legislative agenda that congress actually usually adheres too. This is why you see large, sweeping legislative agendas like The New Deal, Square Deal, and Great Society or even specific bills like Obamacare that are largely attributed to presidential leadership.

As somebody outside the US, I find it pretty crazy how little power the president actually has. Everything goes through congress. And it's a useless congress that (because they have an election cycle every two years) only cares about being re-elected. None of the congressman actually care about the will of the people, they only care about getting back into office. That would be fine if the congressman had to represent the people to get elected, but congress make sure that people don't know that congress is in charge of everything. Take the budget for example. The federal budget in the US has to be approved by congress before it goes through. So, congress decide the budget. They decide exactly how much money the government spends and how much they bring in via taxes. So the federal deficit is entirely the fault of congress. Yet what happens when the US gets into further debt? Congress blames the president. Even though that president had literally no say in the federal budget whatsoever.
